title: From Barron’s, October 28, 2019 (Part 1)
text:
[Italics-bold within the brackets are my additions/elaborations] [New M* Discussions doesn’t allow any colors for cut-and-paste from WORD]

MW Cover: John Baumgartner [WFC] likes packaged-food stocks MDLZ, SMPL, NOMD.

Pg M3, Trader: A good week on the strength of cyclicals [energy, tech, industrials, financials]. Global growth may be stabilizing. 10-yr Treasury yield rose. Dr Copper rose. Rotation from growth to value continued. The Fed is expected to cut short-term rates this week. Earnings were mixed.

Walmart [WMT] is attractive. It reports on Nov 14 but PG reported great numbers this week and 15% of PG sales are via WMT – although they are quite different stocks, there is a good correlation between them. WMT is growing its online, grocery-pickup-and-delivery, health clinic businesses and those bring additional traffic to help its core retail business. And AMZN stumbled this week.

Halloween is typically good for the market. Add that to other market lores – bad seasonality May 1 – October 31, good seasonality Nov 1 – April 30, Santa rally, January effect, Summer doldrums [or rally], etc.

[The CME FedWatch tool, based on current fed fund futures quotes, shows the following probabilities for 2019:

For 3rd hike [cut],

0% for hike [93.5% for cut] at FOMC 10/30/19;

0% for hike [95.1% for cut] at FOMC 12/11/19;

http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html ]

For the week [index changes only], DJIA +0.70%, SP500 +1.22%, Nasdaq Comp +1.90%, Russell 2000 +1.51%. DJ Transports +3.31%; DJ Utilities +0.11%. US$ +0.57%, oil/WTI +5.36%, gold +0.76%.

YTD [index changes only], DJIA +15.56%, SP500 +20.57%, Nasdaq Comp +24.23%.

Pg M6, Europe: Anglo-German travel giant TUI [TUI.uk/TUIFY; fwd P/E 10.3] is attractive. It has been hurt by recent turmoil in travel industry, Brexit, Boeing 737 MAX. It has grown by acquisition. The integrated travel provider owns travel agencies, hotels, airlines, cruise ships, retail stores.

Pg M6, Emerging Markets: China has hundreds of super-startups [Unicorns] and several were supposed to go public this year but didn’t. Many have high revenue growth but obscure paths to profits. Almost half of the joint-venture companies are owned/funded by BABA and TCEHY and they are in no rush for IPOs. The US-China trade tensions have made the US listings problematic. HK demonstrations make HK listings unattractive. Chinese authorities have restricted domestic IPOs and 1,000+ companies are already on waiting list for IPOs.

Pg M11, Commodities: Silver [SLV +14.7% YTD] is more attractive than gold [GLD +16.7% YTD]. Gold-silver ratio at 85 is much higher than its long-term average of 65. Global silver demand exceeds supply.

Pg M7, Options: Using options to hedge portfolios is suggested as prices are near historic highs.

[SP500 VIX 12.65, SKEW 125.70] [10-Yr TYVIX 4.61] [Yahoo Finance data]

Pg M30, M36: A good week in Europe [Denmark +2.49%, Belgium -3.31%] and a good week in Asia [Singapore +2.37%, New Zealand -3.02%]. The equity CEF index [data to Thursday] outperformed the DJIA and its discount was -4.5%.

Treasury rates 3-mo yield 1.66%, 2-yr 1.63%, 5-yr 1.62%, 10-yr 1.80%, 30-yr 2.29% [Treasury data*]. Dollar rose, DXY 97.83, +0.7% [M39]. Gold rose to $1,513, +1.6%; the gold-miners rose [M34]. [^XAU was at 93.54, +3.53% for the week]

*Treasury Yield-Curve https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/interest-rates/Pages/TextView.aspx?data=y...

Top FDIC insured savings deposit rates*: Money-market accounts 2.08%; 1-yr CDs 2.23%; 5-yr CDs 2.76% [M37].

*For local rates https://www.depositaccounts.com/banks/rates-map/

Pg 18: Cover Story, “Big Money Poll/Get Ready for 2020”.

US equities over 12 mo: 42% neutral, 31% bearish, 27% bullish

US valuations: Fairly valued by most

US GDP over 12 mo: 1.5-2.0% by 75%

US recession: 2020H2 – 2021 by 58%

10-yr yield in 12 mo: 1.5-2.0% by 71%

Negative Treasury yields in US: Unlikely by 79%

Oil by 6/30/20: $57.06

Gold by 6/30/20: $1,577

Democratic nominee: Warren by 64%

Presidential winner: Trump by 62%

House Control: Democrats by 80%

Senate Control: Republicans by 80%

Congressional priorities: Entitlement reforms by 25%, cut other federal spending by 20%

US-China trade deal: Never by 40%, before elections by 40%

Tax rates, corporate: Leave unchanged by 79%

Tax rates, individual: Leave unchanged by 54%

Social Security fixes: Raise retirement age by 63%

US climate change policy: Yes by 61%

Tax carried-interest as salary: Yes by 72%

Barron’s Readers Poll: 45% neutral, 29% bullish, 26% bearish

Pg 25: Ahead of elections, there is news on US-China trade, impeachment; possible new regulations on banks, oil drillers; wealth tax, etc. Political risks have grown. There are fewer moderates and there is lack of bipartisanship. Sectors most affected by elections have been IT, consumer-discretionary, healthcare, materials. Ignore political noise and focus on actual policies. Be opportunistic id sectors or stocks overreact to political projections or developments. Ben Phillips of EventShares ETF PLCY offers some names for sports betting [BYD, PENN, TRWH, CHDN], infrastructure [AQUA, GVA, STRL, ASTE, NVEE, ROAD], ethanol production [REX, GPRE, REGI], shipping and IMO 2020 [STNG, SBLK, DSSI, PBF, VLO, HFC].

Pg 5, Up & Down Wall Street: Cyclicals [US and global] are showing good technical strength. Bad news may be good for cyclicals as they benefit the most from stimulus of last several months. Bond yields bottom when recession fears peak, and we may have passed that point. German DAX is breaking out while the German economy is poor. EMs are also breaking out. We will soon enter favorable seasonality period [Nov 1 – April 30].

Since the Fed started cutting rates in July 2018, the SP 500 has been flat. The Fed is expected to cut again next week and then pause for a while. The PCE is below 2% target. Globally, there have been 40 rate cuts in the past 3 months; rates peaked 12 months ago; $13.3 trillion in bonds have negative yields [vs $17 trillion in late-August]. The effects of monetary stimulus should be kicking in soon. Lagarde takes over at the ECB on November 1 and she is expected to continue Draghi’s easy monetary policies.

Pg 9, Streetwise: Tesla/TSLA CEO Elon Musk’s potentially $56 billion, 10-yr pay package goes to Delaware court soon. The case will focus on conflicts and process, less on the pay amount(s).

More later….

YBB
